Comment: I took a great risk, as often, and finally we went into such a tactical position we both where overwhelmed by complications. Finally, a thrilling draw was decided.
I almost never faced the English opening. This can't be bad, contesting the white diagonal.
Opening the lines for my dsb, already preparing c5.
Opening the lines for my dsb, already preparing c5.
Protecting the pin on the knight, so to keep power on central white squares. On the other side, many would regard this move as a loss of tempo.
Protecting the pin on the knight, so to keep power on central white squares. On the other side, many would regard this move as a loss of tempo.
Protecting the pin on the knight, so to keep power on central white squares. On the other side, many would regard this move as a loss of tempo.
No danger of blocking my own diag...
If c5, after the exchange, my d pawn would be free to advance, but for piece protection.
If c5, after the exchange, my d pawn would be free to advance, but for piece protection.
The diag is opened again.
The diag is opened again.
A little mistake, I would say, because now I will take it.
Finally, I exchanged the knight white was taking care of.
True is that my dsb has few places to go. I try to avoid Be7-like moves.
Bd3 was good enough. Exchanging the lsb leaves me without any "good" piece.
Bd3 was good enough. Exchanging the lsb leaves me without any "good" piece.
Just provoking...
A tempo was lost, but now white has to defend the white diagonal.
A tempo was lost, but now white has to defend the white diagonal.
Why not f6 first?

Now... (I must confess that I went through the GK database, findind a similar - not identical - position... it was played by a very high rated player, and it seemed to hold, even considering white's c4 at some point)
c4, cxB, cxB, Qxd5 was ok to me.
c4, cxB, cxB, Qxd5 was ok to me.
An even position, where white's developement is countered by the open position of his king.
According to GK engine, c5 was better, here.
According to GK engine, c5 was better, here.

I needed an escape square for the bishop. Maybe c5 was better, but the pawn's sac opened the way to the white king, still uncastled, and gives me a wondeful c5 spot for the bishop. dxe5, fxe5, Nxe5, Bd6, Bf4, Qe7. Still, the GK engine doesn't agree, and recommends white to play the exchange. This is already difficult to address...

And here starts the hard work: a lot of lines. I saved some of them during the game. This apparent pawn sac is good for black, I think, since...

16.	c3-c4		Be6. If now white goes on with the exchanges, 
17.	d4xe5		BxNg4. If white retakes, Nxe5, and there is no pawn to threat the knight. But what if...
18.	e5xf6		Bc5+ 
19.	Kg1-g2	Qxf6 (threatening the rook)
20.	f3xB		Qxa1 wins material, but leaves the king wide open. 
21.	Qe2+		Be7 (Kd8 would lose the queen after Bf4+)
22.	Bg5		Qxa3
23.	Re1		Nf6 and it seems that black holds, with a solid +6 in material. 
But probably white will not go into this. 

White can choose to go directly into the central exchange: 
16.	d4-e5		f6xe5
17.	Re1		Bc5+
18.	Kg2		o-o
19.	Nxe5		Qf6 It comes again the theme "black diagonal", while f3 is threatened at the cost of the knight d7, that can't be taken. If...
20.	Nxd7		Bxf3+
21.	Qxf3		Qxf3+
22.	Kh3		QxBd3, with huge material advantage and a mate net almost ready.
